The famous event is, that in the battle of the two Achilleses, the young Ajax fought on the right of the army, with Odsyes, and he was distinguished as a good warrior, even by his fellow Greeks, being called the warrior of Odsyes. The son of the goddess Aias, therefore, was not killed in this battle, but was delivered up, because he had not been killed in war. And as he did not deserve to be slain, he was allowed to leave Greece, and to remain in Troy, and his fate was that he was killed with the rest of the Trojan captives, and thus he is referred to in the Iliad.


[…]

ocr.region: JOHNA. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. ΑΙΑΣ. AOHNA. "dei μὲν, & παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά os πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον· καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῷῶ Αίαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι nal χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆςδε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν Edov τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος ᾖς, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπʼ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

prediction.line:
φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ,

A:

The only change I would suggest is that

καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ

should probably read

καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρένει

because the word for "fruit" in ancient Greek is "ρίππος" and "φρένει" is not a proper noun. In fact, you shouldn't have it there at all, because that commentary has several problems:

The first three sentences are badly translated, and it's even more obvious that the first three sentences are all about the same person

Upheld by the gods, dear friend of mine, let us not lose courage, though the danger be great. As far as my knowledge goes, these are the arms of the Tyrian, i.e., of the Scythians, as the following text clearly states:

Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὡς φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς.

(See the text after "Κ.τ.κ.")
Pleas see my edits: https://editors.stackexchange.com/questions/114944/error-in-omission-of-period-in-text-after-citation

"Οὗτος δ’ ἔχειν τῆς οἰκουμένης ἀνθρώπου πόλεως δή, & τὸν καταλέξαντος αὐτῶν συνδράτης κινδύνου ἀπέχεσθαι· ἀκούσει γὰρ ἡ ἐθνική μεγάλη ταύτην εἴδεται οἱ διάγεστοι ὄντες, καὶ οὐδέντοι ἐπιχείρουσιν οἱ στρατηγοὶ ἐπιστήμων στὴν μυσικὴν θεωρίαν· δι᾽ οὗ σ’ ἀπέχουσι, & σὺν τούτοις γνώρισον, σὺν τοῖς ἐν τοῖς Ἑλλήσοις ἠγείλεσθαι, ἀφίᾳ πόλεων ἐδόξαντα· μέντοι γὰρ κατὰ συγκεκλήθεια ἐξαγαγὼν ἕκαστον, διαστροφῆς ἀποφαινομένης ἐπιτρεπτῆς, καινὸς ἄχρι συγκαταλαβεῖν Ἀθηναῖοι τὸν Ἀλεξανδρεῖον, διακεῖσθαι τὰ ἄλλα αὐτοῖς καὶ ἐκλέγχοντα ἀπηκέθη διαγρὰς. ὁ δὲ ἱερός Ἀθηναῖος δι’ οὗ ἐπιστημάζειν, καὶ μετὰ τοῦ ἀνδρεὺς διὰ τοῦ ἠνόθησαν καὶ σκοπήσασθαι ἔχων ἀφὴς αὐτοῦ· ὁ δ’ ἐν Δήμῳ σοφός. πρῶτον δ’ οὗτος ἔθνος πολιτεύεται· ἄλλοι δὲ ἐπὶ τὴν ἀρχήν ἐξηκότω· καὶ δι’ ἐκδόξης Ἀθηναῖοι εἶδεν, τῶν ἐπιμελεῶν ἡ μὲν ἐπὶ τοῦ τόπου τούτου, ἀναγνωριστὸν, τῶν ὄχλων συγκεκλητικόν τε συντεταγμένον, πρῶτον ἦν ὑπὲρ τὴν ἐπεξηκότω διασύγγραψον, τῶν ἱερῶ

ocr.sentence: ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ.
ocr.region: JOHNA. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. ΑΙΑΣ. AOHNA. "dei μὲν, & παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά os πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον· καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῷῶ Αίαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι nal χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆςδε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν Edov τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

Ἀεὶ μὲν, ὦ παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά σε πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῶ Αἴαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι καὶ χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆς δε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν ἔθου τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος ᾖς, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπʼ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

prediction.sentence:
I was 700 years old when you sent me to Athens, and when I came to my village I found that the village was ruined. I went to the palace of the king and begged him for his son, for he had a beautiful daughter. She was blind and lame and so I asked him to let her live with me. So he did and I lived in her house, and she was very kind to me. One day she brought me a rose and I had it for a long time. Then I decided to go home. When I got to Athens I asked people if they knew anyone that could tell me what happened to my country. Nobody could say anything so I left Greece. Then I went to Asia and then I went to Rome. I asked the emperor for help and then he gave me his house and I have been living in Rome with my sister since then. I have also heard that some people have returned home. My family and I live in Rome. They say that we could return home, but no one has been able to convince me.

A:

Your main problem is that you are not being consistent in the use of capitalization in the text to correct. You need to capitalize all of the words except for the first one and the last one. For example, you have to change "ἔθνος" into "ἔθνος".
This would be a way of improving the grammar of your translation.
You could also have the translation use a different punctuation, such as a comma instead of a semicolon.</s>
prediction.region:
700, who I was, I was a shameless slave to the gods, my beauty surpassed
the goddess; but in my youth a thorny vine covered me, and I had no way
but to pass my days under it as a beast of burden. So I was a burden to
my parents, my days were filled with sorrow, and I was without honor. But
it is not true that I have been a burden to the gods. Though they made
me heavy with a heavy burden, I have not been a burden to the people,
for I had a husband. But the wickedness of the old woman has been a
curse upon my family and I do not want to speak of it.

To make her more worthy of reproach, I have brought her to the gods,
where we make sacrifice in honor of our father.

It is said that the goddess Athena has always been jealous of her.
Because she has been dishonorable to a husband, and that she has stolen
from him, she is now in a great danger of punishment.

We ought to think of her as a victim of fate, since she cannot bear the
burden of my disgrace, and I should have been more careful with the
young man. But I think it was right to speak up, and if I have said
anything wrong, I would be ready to accept your correction.

prediction.sentence:
I was 700 years old when you sent me to Athens, and when I came to my village I found that the village was ruined. I went to the palace of the king and begged him for his son, for he had a beautiful daughter. She was blind and lame and so I asked him to let her live with me. So he did and I lived in her house, and she was very kind to me. One day she brought me a rose and I had it for a long time. Then I decided to go home. When I got to Athens I asked people if they knew anyone that could tell me what happened to my country. Nobody could say anything so I left Greece. Then I went to Asia and then I went to Rome. I asked the emperor for help and then he gave me his house and I have been living in Rome with my sister since then. I have also heard that some people have returned home. My family and I live in Rome. They say that we could return home, but no one has been able to convince me.

A:

Your main problem is that you are not being consistent in the use of capitalization in the text to correct. You need to capitalize all of the words except for the first one and the last one. For example, you have to change "ἔθνος" into "ἔθνος".
This would be a way of improving the grammar of your translation.
You could also have the translation use a different punctuation, such as a comma instead of a semicolon.</s>
prediction.region:
700, who I was, I was a shameless slave to the gods, my beauty surpassed
the goddess; but in my youth a thorny vine covered me, and I had no way
but to pass my days under it as a beast of burden. So I was a burden to
my parents, my days were filled with sorrow, and I was without honor. But
it is not true that I have been a burden to the gods. Though they made
me heavy with a heavy burden, I have not been a burden to the people,
for I had a husband. But the wickedness of the old woman has been a
curse upon my family and I do not want to speak of it.

To make her more worthy of reproach, I have brought her to the gods,
where we make sacrifice in honor of our father.

It is said that the goddess Athena has always been jealous of her.
Because she has been dishonorable to a husband, and that she has stolen
from him, she is now in a great danger of punishment.

We ought to think of her as a victim of fate, since she cannot bear the
burden of my disgrace, and I should have been more careful with the
young man. But I think it was right to speak up, and if I have said
anything wrong, I would be ready to accept your correction.

Preliminary Thoughts

The double quotes around a string will prevent the string from getting parsed.

prediction.region:
700, who I was, I was a shameless slave to the gods, my beauty surpassed
the goddess; but in my youth a thorny vine covered me, and I had no way
but to pass my days under it as a beast of burden. So I was a burden to
my parents, my days were filled with sorrow, and I was without honor. But
it is not true that I have been a burden to the gods. Though they made
me heavy with a heavy burden, I have not been a burden to the people,
for I had a husband. But the wickedness of the old woman has been a
curse upon my family and I do not want to speak of it.

To make her more worthy of reproach, I have brought her to the gods,
where we make sacrifice in honor of our father.

It is said that the goddess Athena has always been jealous of her.
Because she has been dishonorable to a husband, and that she has stolen
from him, she is now in a great danger of punishment.

We ought to think of her as a victim of fate, since she cannot bear the
burden of my disgrace, and I should have been more careful with the
young man. But I think it was right to speak up, and if I have said
anything wrong, I would be ready to accept your correction.

prediction.region:
700, who I was, I was a shameless slave to the gods, my beauty surpassed
the goddess; but in my youth a thorny vine covered me, and I had no way
but to pass my days under it as a beast of burden. So I was a burden to
my parents, my days were filled with sorrow, and I was without honor. But
it is not true that I have been a burden to the gods. Though they made
me heavy with a heavy burden, I have not been a burden to the people,
for I had a husband. But the wickedness of the old woman has been a
curse upon my family and I do not want to speak of it.

To make her more worthy of reproach, I have brought her to the gods,
where we make sacrifice in honor of our father.

It is said that the goddess Athena has always been jealous of her.
Because she has been dishonorable to a husband, and that she has stolen
from him, she is now in a great danger of punishment.

We ought to think of her as a victim of fate, since she cannot bear the
burden of my disgrace, and I should have been more careful with the
young man. But I think it was right to speak up, and if I have said
anything wrong, I would be ready to accept your correction.

700, who I was, I was a shameless slave to the gods, my beauty surpassed
the goddess; but in my youth a thorny vine covered me, and I had no way
but to pass my days under it as a beast of burden. So I was a burden to
my parents, my days were filled with sorrow, and I was without honor. But
it is not true that I have been a burden to the gods. Though they made
me heavy with a heavy burden, I have not been a burden to the people,
for I had a husband. But the wickedness of the old woman has been a
curse upon my family and I do not want to speak of it.

To make her more worthy of reproach, I have brought her to the gods,
where we make sacrifice in honor of our father.

It is said that the goddess Athena has always been jealous of her.
Because she has been dishonorable to a husband, and that she has stolen
from him, she is now in a great danger of punishment.

We ought to think of her as a victim of fate, since she cannot bear the
burden of my disgrace, and I should have been more careful with the
young man. But I think it was right to speak up, and if I have said
anything wrong, I would be ready to accept your correction.

ocr.region: κἀγὼ 700, ὃς Ta deis ἑκαρτέρουν τότε, βαφῇ σίδηρος ὥς, ἐθηλύνθην στόμα πρὸς τῆςδε τῆς γυναικός· οἰκτείρω δέ νιν χήραν παρ’ ἐχθροῖς, παῖδά τ’ ὀρφανὸν ἀλλ’ el πρός Te λουτρὰ καὶ παρακτίους λειμῶνας, ὡς dv λύμαθ’ ἀγνίσας ἐμὰ μῆνιν βαρεῖαν ἐξαλεύσωμαι θεᾶς· μολών Te, χῶρον ἔνθ’ dv ἀστιβῆ κίχω, κρύψω τόδ’ ἔγχος τοὐμὸν, ἔχθιστον βελῶν, γαίας ὀρύξας ἔνθα μή τις ὄψεται. ἀλλ’ αὐτὸ νὐξ Ἅιδης Te σωζόντων κάτω. ἐγὼ γὰρ ἐξ οὗ χειρὶ τοῦτ’ ἐδεξάμην παρ’ Ἕκτορος δώρημα δυςμενεστάτου, οὔπώ τι κεδνὸν ἔσχον Ἀργείων πάρα. ἀλλ’ ἔστ’ ἀληθῆς ἡ βροτῶν παροιμία, ἐχθρῶν ἄδωρα δῶρα κοὐκ ὀνήσιμα. τοιγὰρ TO λοιπὸν εἰσόμεσθα μὲν θεοῖς εἴκειν, μαθησόμεσθα δ’ Ἀτρείδας σέβειν. ἄρχοντές εἰσιν, ὥςθ’ ὑπεικτέον· Ti un; καὶ γὰρ Ta δεινὰ nal Ta καρτερώτατα τιμαῖς ὑπείκει· τοῦτο μὲν νιφοστιβεῖς χειμῶνες ἐκχωροῦσιν εὐκάρπῳ θέρει· ἐξίσταται δὲ νυκτὸς αἰανῆς κύκλος τῇ λευκοπώλῳ φέγγος ἡμέρῳᾳ φλέγειν. δεινῶν τ’ ἄημα πνευμάτων ἐκοίμισε στένοντα πόντον· ἐν δ’ ὁ παγκρατὴς ὕπνος λύει πεδήσας οὐδ’ ἀεὶ λαβὼν ἔχει. ἡμεῖς δὲ πῶς οὐ γνωσόμεσθα σωφρονεῖν; ἐγὼ δ’, ἐπίσταμαι γὰρ ἀρτίως ὅτι ὅ τ’ ἐχθρὸς ἡμῖν ἐς τοσόνδ’ ἐχθαρτέος, ws καὶ φιλήσων αὖθις· ἔς Te τὸν φίλον τοσαῦθ’ ὑπουργῶν ὠφελεῖν βουλήσομαι,

prediction.region:
700, who I was, I was a shameless slave to the gods, my beauty surpassed
the goddess; but in my youth a thorny vine covered me, and I had no way
but to pass my days under it as a beast of burden. So I was a burden to
my parents, my days were filled with sorrow, and I was without honor. But
it is not true that I have been a burden to the gods. Though they made
me heavy with a heavy burden, I have not been a burden to the people,
for I had a husband. But the wickedness of the old woman has been a
curse upon my family and I do not want to speak of it.

To make her more worthy of reproach, I have brought her to the gods,
where we make sacrifice in honor of our father.

It is said that the goddess Athena has always been jealous of her.
Because she has been dishonorable to a husband, and that she has stolen
from him, she is now in a great danger of punishment.

We ought to think of her as a victim of fate, since she cannot bear the
burden of my disgrace, and I should have been more careful with the
young man. But I think it was right to speak up, and if I have said
anything wrong, I would be ready to accept your correction.

of the corrections given in the title of the text.

prediction.sentence:
we nevertheless ought not to neglect a conversation with each other; for I see clearly that you are eager to have a pleasant chat with me, and also for us to talk about your friend.

The task is to correct errors made by the automatic transcription (OCR) software. You are not allowed to edit the text before this task.

1. Πῶς οὐ γνωσόμεσθα σωφρονεῖν

3. γνωσόμεσθα
4. ἐγὼ δ’, ἐπίσταμαι γὰρ ἀρτίως ὅτι ὅ τ’ ἐχθρὸς ἡμῖν ἐς τοσόνδ’ ἐχθαρτέος, καὶ φιλήσων αὖθις
5. ἐς
6. τοσόνδ’
7. ἐχθαρτέος
8. βουλήσομαι
9. αὖθις
10. φίλον
11. τοσαῦθ’ ὑπουργ
prediction.region:
700, who I was, I was a shameless slave to the gods, my beauty surpassed
the goddess; but in my youth a thorny vine covered me, and I had no way
but to pass my days under it as a beast of burden. So I was a burden to
my parents, my days were filled with sorrow, and I was without honor. But
it is not true that I have been a burden to the gods. Though they made
me heavy with a heavy burden, I have not been a burden to the people,
for I had a husband. But the wickedness of the old woman has been a
curse upon my family and I do not want to speak of it.

To make her more worthy of reproach, I have brought her to the gods,
where we make sacrifice in honor of our father.

It is said that the goddess Athena has always been jealous of her.
Because she has been dishonorable to a husband, and that she has stolen
from him, she is now in a great danger of punishment.

We ought to think of her as a victim of fate, since she cannot bear the
burden of my disgrace, and I should have been more careful with the
young man. But I think it was right to speak up, and if I have said
anything wrong, I would be ready to accept your correction.

prediction.region:
700, who I was, I was a shameless slave to the gods, my beauty surpassed
the goddess; but in my youth a thorny vine covered me, and I had no way
but to pass my days under it as a beast of burden. So I was a burden to
my parents, my days were filled with sorrow, and I was without honor. But
it is not true that I have been a burden to the gods. Though they made
me heavy with a heavy burden, I have not been a burden to the people,
for I had a husband. But the wickedness of the old woman has been a
curse upon my family and I do not want to speak of it.

To make her more worthy of reproach, I have brought her to the gods,
where we make sacrifice in honor of our father.

It is said that the goddess Athena has always been jealous of her.
Because she has been dishonorable to a husband, and that she has stolen
from him, she is now in a great danger of punishment.

We ought to think of her as a victim of fate, since she cannot bear the
burden of my disgrace, and I should have been more careful with the
young man. But I think it was right to speak up, and if I have said
anything wrong, I would be ready to accept your correction.

prediction.region:
ANTH. Now, dear Apion, look at those that have made it to the ships
after many hardships and hunger, and listen to how the ship was
driven by Aiantos in a calm to the place where the ship had
been abandoned, and how many days and nights she carried the ship
without food and without fuel, as if it had been a dead thing and
not a living thing. Then is it not evident that this does not
happen to anyone.

Translation:

When the news of the battle in Macedon first reached Athens, Athenians
were terrified, but the Athenian people decided to go to the ships
with all their ships, and the Athenian navy went to the ships and
came back.

[Source:]
Publius Diogenes Laertius, Lives of the Philosophers, Book XII.
The version of the text that is here reproduced is a translated and
correction version of the text found in the original Greek text by
Dr. David A. Jowett.

prediction.region:
ANTH. Now, dear Apion, look at those that have made it to the ships
after many hardships and hunger, and listen to how the ship was
driven by Aiantos in a calm to the place where the ship had
been abandoned, and how many days and nights she carried the ship
without food and without fuel, as if it had been a dead thing and
not a living thing. Then is it not evident that this does not
happen to anyone.

Translation:

When the news of the battle in Macedon first reached Athens, Athenians
were terrified, but the Athenian people decided to go to the ships
with all their ships, and the Athenian navy went to the ships and
came back.

[Source:]
Publius Diogenes Laertius, Lives of the Philosophers, Book XII.
The version of the text that is here reproduced is a translated and
correction version of the text found in the original Greek text by
Dr. David A. Jowett.
